Moments later, RogliÄ roared crossed the line ahead of an ecstatic throng of Slovenian fans a stage-winner to carve out a 14-second winning margin over Geraint Thomas, the fourth-smallest in race history.

After nearly three weeks of struggling to find form, shaking off two heavy crashes, avoiding COVID, and leaning on a young, relatively inexperienced squad of replacement riders, RogliÄ erased all the demons from the 2020 meltdown and more.

And he did it with a single chainring and a massive, 10-44t SRAM XPLR cassette built for gravel racing. What an ending.

Completing the Giro circle: â€˜PrimoÅ¾ always comes back strongerâ€™

The RogliÄ party carried all the way from the steep slopes of Monte Lussari â€” quite literally down the road from where he used to hurl his body off ski jumps in his teens â€” to the Coliseum of Rome on Sunday to wrap the 2023 Giro.

â€œI made it thanks to the crowd. Iâ€™ll never forget the support of all these people,â€ RogliÄ said. â€œI had goosebumps and tears in my eyes when I saw all these people cheering for me. I didnâ€™t care so much about the result. Iâ€™m incredibly proud to be the rider they came here for.â€

Decked out in head-to-toe in pink with a matching pink bike, RogliÄâ€™s victory marked the completion of the Giro circle that began nearly a decade ago.

After showing promise in his grand tour debut at the 2016 Giro, when he won a time trial to finish a distant 58th, RogliÄ seemed destined to become Sloveniaâ€™s first grand tour winner.

By 2019, after winning stages at back-to-back editions of the Tour de France and finishing fourth overall in 2018, he returned to the Giro intent on winning.

No one had heard of Tadej Pogacar, and the Giro seemed like RogliÄâ€™s moment of arrival, but Richard Carapaz rode away from everyone, delivering the first of stinging GC disappointments that would haunt RogliÄ the next few seasons.

Yet as his teammate Sepp Kuss said Saturday, RogliÄ harbors an innate ability to shake off adversity like a morning chill.

Crashing out of both the Tour and Vuelta a EspaÃ±a in 2022 saw RogliÄ on the back foot all spring, but he dug deep with trademark, hard-edged resolve in the closing three stages of the Giroâ€™s final week.

Kuss, who is a GC talisman of sorts in grand tours, helped set the winning pace across the Dolomites.

â€œThatâ€™s PrimoÅ¾, even with adversity, he comes back stronger,â€ Kuss said. â€œItâ€™s just amazing. Itâ€™s beautiful for him to be here with all the Slovenian fans, itâ€™s just beyond words.

RogliÄ didnâ€™t look his sharpest going into Fridayâ€™s â€œqueen stageâ€ to Tre Cime, and everything was still tightly wound among the top-3.

In a race that was hyped as a two-horse race between Remco Evenepoel and RogliÄ, the ever-steady presence of Geraint Thomas and the proud Ineos Grenadiers train was chugging confidently into the final weekend with a 29-second lead.

â€œFive days after my second crash in the Giro, I still struggled a bit but I kept fighting,â€ said RogliÄ, referring to the week-two spill that also took out Tao Geoghegan Hart. â€œI made it thanks to this crowd. Iâ€™ll never forget the support of all these people.â€

After studying the brutal third week and the beyond-steep slopes of Fridayâ€™s and Saturdayâ€™s stages, RogliÄ and Jumbo-Visma decided to change the script.

With two climbs to go in Fridayâ€™s â€œqueen stage,â€ RogliÄ swapped the road bike set-up for a single chainring crank with an 11-44t gravel-racing SRAM XPLR cassette. The strategic swap was designed to give RogliÄ extra spin on Tre Cime, but it looked like he was running out of gas in the high altitude high in the Dolomites on Friday.

Thomas opened up a surge with 400m to and it appeared he would even widen his lead when RogliÄ pounced with one well-timed acceleration that gapped the gasping Thomas and earned him back three seconds.

That was the first warning shot.

Momentum seemed on RogliÄâ€™s side going into Saturdayâ€™s time trial, but Thomas wasnâ€™t going to go down with a fight. Equally pride, but with nothing to prove, the 2018 Tour winner was out to remind everyone he owns something RogliÄ still doesnâ€™t â€” the Tourâ€™s yellow jersey.

Saturdayâ€™s time trial brought eery similarities to the 2020 Tour disaster, except this time RogliÄ was the attacker, and Thomas took the final starting spot. The tables were turned, and the first tell-tale sign that things might go RogliÄâ€™s way came at the bike-swap transition zone.

â€œWe practiced the substitution seven or eight times,â€ RogliÄ said Saturday. â€œI knew that the final time trial was the decisive day. I knew that from experience. I did it today. With this crowd and these people. It truly is a day I will remember for the rest of my life.â€

RogliÄâ€™s smooth swap was a model of Formula 1 efficiency as he clicked back onto his one-ring gravel-equipped groupset and sped off again, while Thomas came to a complete stop after he not only swapped bikes but for a better ventilated climbing helmet as well.

The gap started to widen. Thomasâ€™s lead was shrinking as fast as the road got steep.Â Then the chain slipped.

RogliÄ wins battle of nerves: â€˜Finally I had luck on my sideâ€™

Jumbo-Vismaâ€™s decision to ride the oversized cassette went from what appeared to be a stroke of genius to cyclingâ€™s biggest boondoggle in a matter of seconds. The risk of losing the chain is higher with a single ring, and though it shouldnâ€™t slip on a climb, it did.

â€œI was waiting at the finish line. Then it seems as if things are always going too slowly,â€ Engels said. â€œWhen he had a problem with his bike I thought it was over, but luckily he stayed calm, and could carry on.â€

Their fates reconnected just at the right time, and RogliÄ was quickly back on the road to pink.

Saturdayâ€™s apogee was a fitting finale of a slow-boil Giro. After a string of high-profile abandons, poor weather, and a back-end course design, all the tension, fatigue, and ambition poured out in raw, unedited passion across the Dolomites.

Even if some wonder what might have happened if the likes of Evenepoel, Aleksandr Vlasov, or Geoghegan Hart were still in the race, the tape reveals that RogliÄ was consistent across the entire race.

RogliÄ is never one to wear his emotions on his sleeve, but his eyes welled up as he kissed his wife and hugged his young son.
